awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: F: Metric-space Positioning Systems for Symbolic Data Science
awd_abstract_narration:
Next-generation DNA sequencing technologies produce datasets that are the epitome of "big data." Resulting files are typically quite large, consisting almost entirely of symbolic (i.e., non-numeric) short DNA sequences. In contrast, the most widely used machine learning algorithms require numerical datasets to learn. Unfortunately, both traditional and cutting-edge methods to numerically represent symbolic data often suffer from high-dimensionality or substantial running time requirements, which hinder the application of powerful machine learning algorithms to modern biological questions. To overcome these crucial issues, this project addresses the fundamental problem of determining the "right" dimension in which to embed symbolic data for a data-mining or classification task. It does so by representing symbolic datasets numerically via a method reminiscent of Global Positioning Systems (GPS) but in a far more general setting. Besides exploring modern biology applications, the project will also investigate how to predict the source of a spread (i.e., ground zero) over large networks. This may assist administrators in determining how best to respond to new epidemics and cyber-threats. Additionally, the project will closely mentor undergraduate and graduate students to become mature data scientists. Its findings will be communicated as notes, open-source software, and video-lectures available to the general public, including students in the Colorado Data Science Team, which encourages the participation of women and under-represented minorities in Engineering education.

Much like GPS uses trilateration to locate a receiver anywhere on the planet, finite metric spaces contain resolving sets, that is sets of points that uniquely identify every point in the space via multilateration (i.e., the vector of distances to points in the set). Associated with any resolving set R, there is a one-to-one transformation from its ambient metric space to a Euclidean space of dimension |R|, the cardinality of R. The smallest resolving set thus induces the lowest-dimensional representation of its ambient space. Importantly, even when the ambient metric space is finite but exponentially large, its metric dimension is often much smaller than its cardinality. Determining the metric dimension is, however, an NP-hard problem in a variety of contexts. Building on this abstracted notion of multilateration, this project will: (1) assess the computational complexity of calculating the metric dimension of Hamming graphs, and characterize the metric dimension of various random graph models to guide the development of new and efficient algorithms to approximate this quantity; (2) explore relaxations and constraints of multilateration, including approximate and probabilistic algorithms, to expand the reach of applications of multilateration to other finite but large metric spaces; and finally (3) provide proofs-of-concept of multilateration to learn non-contiguous regions of dependencies in genomic sequences, develop classifiers for historically elusive virus targets, and identify the source of spread of information or disease in large networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Symbolic Data Science, a largely unexplored and innovative domain, has been the central focus of this project. In a world where many contemporary datasets are symbolic or have symbolic metadata unsuitable for traditional statistical or machine learning techniques, this project represents a significant effort to elevate Symbolic Data Science into a recognized field, offering a fresh and unique approach to data analysis.

This project primarily focused on challenges associated with "metric dimension" and the closely related notion of a "resolving set." In essence, a resolving set consists of a group of "landmarks" that can uniquely identify a position, place, or point within a space by measuring distances to these landmarks. The metric dimension of a space refers to the least number of such landmarks required for unique determination. These concepts are generalizations of the method of trilateration used to locate a place in a map based on its distance to three points forming a triangle. In complex spaces, however, particularly abstract ones, more than three landmarks may be needed, which led this project to coin the term "multi-lateration" to describe the key idea more precisely.

Multilateration is very useful for representing symbolic objects as numerical vectors because it induces similar representations for similar objects. These representations operate like a Social Security Number (SSN), except that objects with similar SSN digits are guaranteed to possess similar characteristics. Multilateration, therefore, can be used to represent symbolic data or metadata numerically to take advantage of cutting-edge statistical and machine learning techniques, which often demand numerical rather than symbolic inputs.

This project has not only delved into the theoretical aspects of multilateration but also explored practical applications. It has successfully represented DNA sequences, proteins, and points in hypercubes and generalizations of the latter, the Hamming and Levenshtein graphs, as low-dimensional vectors. It has also ventured into applications in natural language processing for sentiment analysis and sarcasm detection, inspiring new possibilities in the field and demonstrating the tangible benefits of this project. 

The project also explored the problem of locating a source of infection (e.g., a user's fake news) in a network (e.g., a social media platform) based on the time the infection reached some "observers" in the network. Additionally, it explored applications in comparative metagenomics to pinpoint crucial mutations that distinguish microbial communities across various environments, potentially paving the way for a computational way for scientific and technological breakthroughs.

All the project applications were achieved alongside mathematical developments, including foundational advancements, to guide the efficient and accurate representation of symbolic or high-dimensional numerical data for analysis and discovery.

The project involved and partially supported ten trainees, ranging from bachelor's to professional master's, master's, and Ph.D. This group included one woman, one LatinX, and one Hispanic student. All trainees were exposed to and learned new mathematical, statistical, or machine learning techniques beyond their standard academic curriculum and gained substantial experience in coding, as well as in collecting or producing, processing, and analyzing large symbolic or numerical datasets. They collectively defended six theses or dissertations and, in collaboration with the PI or co-PI, were involved in seven research manuscripts, with two more under review and another being written. Lastly, the project outcomes were disseminated locally, nationally, and internationally at numerous professional venues, fostering new collaborations with four researchers at different institutions, including a former graduate trainee associated with the project, now an Assistant Professor at Cal State, and a graduate student at UC San Diego.
